comments:
I was remote debugging and I was then presented with a resume failed - I think
when I hit play in debug mode - and then hitting the details button a message
told me to check my log which kept on growing with these same messages until I
killed my remote app.  Eclipse was unresponsive until the remote app terminated.

Looks like the communication with the VM got disconnected without feedback in 
the UI. The model thought it was still connected and attempted to send all 
your commands - resulting in timeouts. Do you have steps to reproduce? Does it 
happen often?

I have only had it happend once but then I haven't been using m7 all that long
and I can probably count the number of times I have been in the debugger on my
fingers.

I don't have repro steps but I was hoping there was something you could fix
based on the stack trace.  If it happens again I'll see if I can repro.

Marking as works for me. Workaround is to increase debugger timeout value if 
required, on the "Java > Debug" preference page.

I think in general that solution is ok but I think that there should be a
counter in the connection code that if a timeout occurs say 500 times within a 2
minute period of time then you should disconnect from the vm and give a warning
with an explanation on how to increase this timeout value.  

I don't think it is accectable to just throw timeout exceptions and have eclipse
lock until the remote vm is shutdown.

Bug 45980 addresses any blocking (i.e. will do hotswap in background job). 
Deferring this bug as a feature request to auto-disconnect when many timeouts 
occurr.

Hello, 
is the feature already implemented in Eclipse 3.2 or planned for a future release? We encoutered a similar problem, that when a timeout connection occurs in an Eclipse 3.1 IDE, the debugger hangs and disconnecting the remote vm is not possible anymore. So, an automatic disconnect when the timeout occurs would be practicable, so we wouldn't need to restart the IDE. Thanks and best regards, Marion
